subtitle: Thinking Allowed
Conversations on the leading edge of knowledge and discovery with psychologist Jeffrey Mishlove
Hello, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove and today, I'd like to talk about self-
discipline.Let me start out by telling you, right at the outset,
I am NOT the most disciplined person in the world. In fact, far from it.
But what I can say is that in my life I’ve gone through
phases where I followed particular disciplines, sometimes for several years,
but then generally they’ve fallen away. At one time, I used to run marathons.
I was a distance runner and it would be
normal for me to run 3, 4, 5, 6 miles
every day. I no longer do that.
At one time I practiced yoga regularly, for years.
I no longer do that. I used to be a much more disciplined
meditator than I am now. I
I have also had a discipline – I call it my “diet diary” – where I keep track of everything I eat,
every day, including counting the calories and
measuring my weight. But that’s also a discipline that comes and goes in my life.
Now, when I started doing this “In Presence” series, I
sort of – in the back of my mind – had an idea that maybe it would become a regular,
daily
discipline of mine, to create a monologue each day for the viewers of the New Thinking Allowed series.
But I wasn’t sure and when I got to number 0024 –
you know – I thought maybe I’d run out of ideas. When I got to number 0048,
I thought, “I don’t know if I can keep doing this anymore.” And now, I see I’m on
0055, and I’m inclined to think, “this would be a really good discipline,
let's see how long I can keep it up." Because there’s a sense in which I’ve picked all the low-hanging fruit
already from the tree, I’m going to have to reach deeper and further into myself to continue the series, and
I don't know how that's going to impact these-
I’m thinking of them as conversations. Because even though it’s a monologue, I know you’re out there.
I read your comments and your feedback,
and my guess is that many of you are probably like me: you’re not the most
disciplined people in the world, but you would like to do what you can to improve your lives.
I bet each and every one of you wants to become the best version of yourself, and isn’t that what
self-discipline is about?
Now my hero, William James, one of my intellectual heroes, has
put it very succinctly. When he wrote about ethics
he talked about – there’s something he called the “strenuous mood” – and that’s what is called for in our day and age.
Laziness doesn't help, even though
we all have, I think, a very healthy instinct to relax, to be lazy, to enjoy life a
little bit, to let go of the rigid disciplines on the one hand, and
yet, on the other hand, we know we could be doing a little better for ourselves.
For example
My mother- my saintly mother-
You know when I was a young man and discontent I once went and saw a Jungian
psychotherapist and I complained, I said, “I wish I had been born into a family of yogis.
How come I had to be born in the
Midwest in Wisconsin from a very average middle-class family?" Well
only a few years later my mother became a yoga teacher, and she kept up that practice for over 25 years.
And
truly she was a saintly human being. And
she used to say
"moderation in all things,
including moderation."
That was how she lived. One of her other maxims was, “whenever you get sick, have some ice cream.”
She loved ice cream and frozen yogurt. When we were children, if I got a sore throat,
“have some ice cream.” It always seemed to work. But I’ll confess, lately I’ve probably been eating too much ice cream.
I don’t think it’s good for me. I have to watch it. I have to make some adjustments, and I plan to,
and I'm telling you that right now.
So, you know, I think most of us know the difference between healthy eating and unhealthy eating, but we don’t always
follow the
guidelines that we’re aware of in the most strenuous way that we could. I think we all know that
a certain amount of exercise each day, of one form or another, is healthy. I bet everybody
viewing this now understands that to take a little time every day for meditation is a good thing to do,
but maybe we don't always do it. And
I suspect for many of you watching these daily
monologues that I'm creating has become something of a discipline for you. And the thing is this:
I'm on video, you see me on your computer screen,
we don't have very much back and forth between us. And
I know
there's a guru who I used to pay quite a bit of attention to
he’s gone by various names: Da Love-Ananda, Da Free John, and so one. But, he once wrote an essay

your efforts to become the best version of yourself will accelerate.
